text:
Something I don't understand.
The US is starting to open up for vaccinating the general population (depending on state).
The UK is not too far away from that either.
But the US has  vaccinated  with at least 1 shot a bit under a third the population, where as the uk has vaccinated a bit under half.

I have 4 possible explanation:
 - US has much lower uptake by choice, because AntiVaxers (That fits a stereotype, but I don't know that it's true. Esp amoungst vulnerable groups)
 - US has much lower uptake due to challenges navigating the system (the system in the US sounds really complex, but complex enough to loose a third of all vulnerable people?)
 - US has fewer vulnerable people due to how they are classifying people. (So they don't have about 50% the  population in any kind of prioritized group. Easy way for this is if the age brackets are cutoff differently. UK's bottom vulnerable group is only 50 years old.)
â€¢ US has fewer vulnerable people due to demographic differences (younger population would be the big one)

elements.text:
Something I don't understand.
The US is starting to open up for vaccinating the general population (depending on state).
The UK is not too far away from that either.
But the US has  vaccinated  with at least 1 shot a bit under a third the population, where as the uk has vaccinated a bit under half.

I have 4 possible explanation:
 - US has much lower uptake by choice, because AntiVaxers (That fits a stereotype, but I don't know that it's true. Esp amoungst vulnerable groups)
 - US has much lower uptake due to challenges navigating the system (the system in the US sounds really complex, but complex enough to loose a third of all vulnerable people?)
 - US has fewer vulnerable people due to how they are classifying people. (So they don't have about 50% the  population in any kind of prioritized group. Easy way for this is if the age brackets are cutoff differently. UK's bottom vulnerable group is only 50 years old.)
US has fewer vulnerable people due to demographic differences (younger population would be the big one)

text: Part of it is due to how quickly the vaccine supply is growing here, and how poor of a job they did in planning for the growth. New appointment slots are being added all the time. A lot of healthy older folks signed up for an appointment on the first day they were able, and got slots weeks away. Then new appointment slots get added in the interim, but no one will fill them unless you open it to younger people. That's what happened in my state at least.

elements.text: Part of it is due to how quickly the vaccine supply is growing here, and how poor of a job they did in planning for the growth. New appointment slots are being added all the time. A lot of healthy older folks signed up for an appointment on the first day they were able, and got slots weeks away. Then new appointment slots get added in the interim, but no one will fill them unless you open it to younger people. That's what happened in my state at least.

text:
Ah I see. that make sense.
There was an interesting (bad) thing here in the UK where some hospitals couldn't vaccinate the last of the top priority group because there wasn't enough of them to use up a full batch of vaccines (which needed to be defrosted 1000 at a time), and so people had to wait til the next group was allowed to be vaccinated. (Probably only effected a few dozen or hundred people with like a week delay.)
